choices.text: Brief staring spells and blank episodes

questions.text: Which of the following is a common characteristic of absence seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Absence seizure is characterized by sudden onset brief staring spells & blank spells of short duration followed by subtle motor signs (Automatism) not preceded by aura & followed by confusion.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by sudden, brief muscle contractions that may cause a person to drop items or fall?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Myoclonic jerks/seizure are sudden onset intermittent  jerky movement making patient drop any item held in the hand.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug is generally considered safe for use during pregnancy due to its low risk of foetal malformations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Levetiracetam ,Lamotrigine & Ox Carbamazepine are three relatively safe anti epileptic drugs having lower risk of foetal malformations.

choices.text: Offer the person a glass of water
Help the person stand up and walk around
Place the person in the recovery position
Attempt to wake the person up by shaking them

questions.text: If you witness someone having a seizure, what should you do immediately after the seizure ends?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


In case of active seizure STAY -SAFE- SIDE protocol should be followed .
Stay with the patient.
Safe -Keep the patient safe -away from obstacles 
Side on recovery should ideally be left lateral to prevent aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used to treat essential tremor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Propranolol -Beta blocker is used for treatment of Essential temors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with asymmetric resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia. On examination, he demonstrates a shuffling gait and a stooped posture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Parkinson Disease is characterized by Resting tremors with cog wheel rigidity & bradykinesia causing a stooped/flexed posture in the patient .Patient can be seen walking with Festinating-ready to run /Shuffling gait.

questions.text: Flapping tremor is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Flapping tremors occur in Hepatic Encephalopathy, Uremic Encephalopathy & CO2 Narcosis .Wilson disease can develop Hepatic Encephalopathy as a complication .

Thyrotoxicosis  has Fine Tremors .

questions.text: The characteristic feature of Parkinsonism consists of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tremor, rigidity, hypokinesia

In Parkinson Disease Tremor, rigidity & Bradykinesia is seen in Parkinsonism .

Tremors are the first motor symptom to appear in Parkinsonism followed by rigidity & Bradykinesia.

questions.text: Match the following Gait disorders
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


I-Scissoring gait seen in Spastic Cerebral Palsy.

II-Festinating gait seen in Parkinson Disease.

III- High steppage/equine gait seen in Foot drop.

IV- Waddling gait seen in Proximal myopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a core clinical feature of Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Visual hallucinations are a core clinical feature of DLB and are often detailed, well-formed, and recurrent. They are one of the distinguishing features that help differentiate DLB from other types of dementia.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurological deficits that resolve within 24 hours. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Abrupt onset neurological deficit recovering completely within 24 hours is defined as Transient ischemic attack (TIA)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location of hypertensive haemorrhage :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Putamen a part of Lentiform nucleus also known as external capsule is most common site of hypertensive intracerebral bleed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with sudden-onset severe headache, vomiting, and altered consciousness. Imaging reveals a subdural hematoma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trauma is most common cause of all extracerebral bleeds like SAH,SDH & EDH.

questions.text: Not a component of thalamic syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Motor weakness would occur in cortical or internal capsule lesion.

Thalamus is a sensory gateway where perception of all sensations occurs. Any thalamic lesions will cause hemi anaesthesia. 

Anterior thalamus is also part of Papez circuit which helps in conversion of short term into long term memory via Hippocampus. So anterior thalamic lesion can cause amnesia.

questions.text: Bilaterally pinpoint pupil, hyperpyrexia and loss of consciousness is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Quadriparesis with pinpoint pupils ,tachycardia ,tachypnoea ,hyperthermia & hyperhidrosis is seen in patients with Pontine haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, she has photophobia and neck stiffness. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


NCCT (Brain) is investigation of choice for diagnosing Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

questions.text: Which one of the following has maximum area of representation in the cerebral motor cortex :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


In motor cortex body parts performing finer skilled activity have larger area of representation .Metacarpophalangeal joint is useful for moving the fingers which perform fine skillful movements.

choices.text: Affects memory transformation from short term to long term.

questions.text: Hippocampus lesion :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Hippocampus is also known as memory gateway which converts short term memory into long term memory via consolidation.

questions.text: A lesion in paracentral lobule causes :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Paracentral lobule located in frontal lobe is the motor cortex for lower limb & also control centre for urinary bladder socially .Any lesion in Paracentral lobule will cause lower limb weakness with urinary incontinence.

questions.text: The characteristic feature of a frontal lobe tumor is :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Pre Frontal area in frontal lobe controls emotions. Any lesion in this area would cause antisocial behaviour.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory modalities is examined in the patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Stereognosis is defined as an ability to recognize an object on touch.

questions.text: Not seen in case of infarction in MCA territory:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Paracentral lobule controlling urinary bladder is supplied by Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) .

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden weakness and numbness on the right side of her body. On examination, she has right-sided hemiparesis and hemisensory loss, along with facial droop and dysarthria. Which of the following arteries is most likely occluded?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MCA infarction will cause hemiplegia, hemianesthesia ,hemianopia with aphasia.

questions.text: A pure motor stroke is most likely with damage to :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pure motor stroke occurs due to lesion at posterior limb of internal capsule ,it is also known as dense hemiparesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of a UMN lesion :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

UMN paralysis is characterized by weakness with spasticity, hyperreflexia & extensor plantar.
Fasciculation is visible & palpable muscle twitch due to lesion at anterior horn cell.

choices.text: Both upper and lower motor neuron signs

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) there is degeneration of Corticospinal tract causing UMN paralysis & Anterior horn cell causing LMN paralysis.

choices.text: Paralysis of the lower half of face on the same side
Paralysis of the lower half of face on the opposite side
Paralysis of the upper half of face on the same side
Paralysis of the upper half of face on the opposite side

questions.text: An upper motor neuron lesion of facial nerve will cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In UMN facial nerve palsy there is paralysis of lower half of the face contralateral to the lesion.
In LMN facial nerve palsy there is facial weakness of complete face on the same side of lesion.

questions.text: Bilateral facial palsy is seen in :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bilateral LMN facial palsy is seen in GBS ,HIV, Sarcoidosis & Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of severe throbbing headaches, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and photophobia. She reports a family history of similar headaches. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Migraine is female predominant headache .It presents with unilateral throbbing pain with nausea

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a headache associated with lacrimation .He reports that these headaches occur in clusters, with several attacks per day over a period of weeks to months, followed by remission. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cluster headache is male predominant headache .It presents with clustered attack of short duration retro orbital explosive pain associated with lacrimation.

questions.text: A woman has bilateral headache that worsens with emotional stress ,she has two children both badly in school diagnosis is :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tension headache is female predominant headache .It presents as band like sensation over the head.

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by presence of Ach receptor antibodies causing destruction of Ach receptors & decreased myoneural junction transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening test for myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ice pack test is best screening test for Myasthenia Gravis where improvement occurs in ocular symptoms after applying ice pack over eyelid.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is primarily involved in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Alzheimer disease there is deficiency of Acetyl Choline due to degeneration of nucleus basalis of Myerenet.

choices.text: Atrophy of parietal and temporal lobes
Atrophy of frontal and temporal lobes
Atrophy of temporal and occipital lobes
Atrophy of parietal and occipital lobes

questions.text: In Alzheimer’s disease, the pathology seen in the brain is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In Alzheimer Disease there is degeneration of temporal lobe causing amnesia & parietal lobe causing apraxia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Normal pressure hydrocephalus :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Normal pressure hydrocephalus as per Hakim triad is characterized by Gait ataxia ,urinary incontinence & dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Huntington Chorea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Huntington chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by chorea, personality changes & dementia.

questions.text: Wernickes encephalopathy during refeeding syndrome can be precipitated in deficiency of which of the following vitamin :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wernicke’s Encephalopathy is due to deficiency of thiamine -Vitamin B1.

choices.text: It is caused by infectious proteins
Brain biopsy is specific for diagnosis

questions.text: All statements about CJD are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Creutzfeldt Jackob Disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative disorder causing by infectious protein PrPsc .Myoclonus (startle) ,ataxia & dementia are main symptoms.
Brain biopsy reveals spongiform degeneration.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Streptococcus pneumoniae is most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults & elderly .It is also known to be most common cause of community acquired meningitis.

questions.text: Characteristic finding in CT in a TBM case is :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Basal exudates are most characteristic imaging finding in TBM.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Guillain-Barré syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gullian Barre syndrome is characterized by bilateral symmetrical ascending paralysis.

choices.text: Corticosteroids used for early recovery and prevent long stay
High dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) can be inititated
High dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) and plasmapheresis are equally effective

questions.text: All are true regarding treatment of Guillian Barre syndrome except :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Corticosteroids are not recommended in treatment of GBS.

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and contralateral spastic paralysis
Ipsilateral loss of fine touch and proprioception, ipsilateral spastic paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation
Contralateral loss of all sensory modalities and ipsilateral flaccid paralysis
Ipsilateral loss of all sensory modalities and contralateral spastic paralysis

questions.text: A patient with Brown-Séquard syndrome is most likely to present with which of the following combinations of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Ipsilateral loss of fine touch and proprioception, ipsilateral spastic paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation
The classical presentation of Brown-Séquard syndrome includes ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception (due to dorsal column involvement), ipsilateral spastic paralysis (due to corticospinal tract damage), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation (due to spinothalamic tract involvement).

choices.text: Upper motor neuron signs in the lower extremities
Lower motor neuron weakness in the upper extremities
Loss of proprioception and vibration sense

questions.text: Which of the following neurological deficits is typically not associated with syringomyelia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Loss of proprioception and vibration sense
Syringomyelia typically causes dissociated sensory loss, where pain and temperature sensation are lost, but proprioception and vibration sense are usually preserved. This is because the syrinx primarily affects the central spinal cord, where the spinothalamic tract fibers cross, while the dorsal columns, which carry proprioception and vibration sense, are often spared.

choices.text: Ketosis commonly occurs on stopping treatment.
Pancreatic beta cell stop producing insulin.
There is increased level of insulin in blood.

questions.text: In a patient with NIDDM which of the following condition is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In Type 2 DM there is insulin resistance causing hyperinsulinemia in the patient .

choices.text: The level of fasting glucose is ≥ 100 mg/dL and that of post-prandial glucose is ≥ 140 mg/dL
The level of fasting glucose is ≥ 125 mg/dL and that of post-prandial glucose is ≥ 199 mg/dL
The level of plasma insulin is ≥ 6 IU/dL

questions.text: Diabetes is diagnosed when –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In Diabetes Mellitus is diagnosed when 
RBS > 200 mg/dl ,FBS >126 mg/dl,Oral GTT >200 mg/dl ,HbA1C >6.5%

questions.text: All of the following laboratory tests are consistent with diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In DKA plasma osmolality remains normal.

questions.text: Hypoglycemic unawareness that occurs in diabetic patients when transferred from OHA to insulin is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In diabetic autonomic neuropathy there is decreased adrenergic surge leading to masking o symptoms of hypoglycaemia causing Hypoglycaemic unawareness.

questions.text: Treatment of 42 year old obese man with blood glucose 450mg,urine albumin 2+,ketone 1+
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Insulin is drug of choice to treat ketosis in hyperglycaemic patient.

choices.text: Morning hyperglycemia due to insufficient insulin.
Morning hypoglycemia due to excess insulin.

questions.text: Dawn phenomenon is :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dawn phenomena is morning hyperglycemia due to insulinopenia caused by insufficient insulin.

questions.text: A young women with secondary amenorrhoea ,galactorrhea and bitemporal heminopia .MRI shows a tumor of 25mm diameter in pituitary fossa.Treatment is;
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dopamine agonist is the treatment of choice for Prolactinoma of any size.

questions.text: 8 months pregnant female with past history of prolactinoma presents with headache and no visual impairement .Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step in her management :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prolactinoma in pregnancy is initially treated with bromocriptine in case of no response surgery (TSR) is advised.

questions.text: All are seen in Gigantism except :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Due to growth hormone excess there is soft tissue proliferation causing organomegaly .Mental retardation is not seen in gigantism.

questions.text: Confirmatory investigation for acromegaly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Best Screening test for Acromegaly -Serum IGF -1 levels.
Confirmatory test – GH suppression test

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features of diabetes insipidus is false :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Diabetes Insipidus (DI) due to increase in serum osmolality there is stimulation of thirst centre .So patient consumes more water to compensate for the loss which has occurred due to polyuria. At the end there is no dehydration in the patient.

questions.text: Choose the best Lab value for patient with central diabetes insipidus:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In central diabetes insipidus there is decrease in urine osmolality with increase in serum osmolality

questions.text: A vasopressin analogue does not produce therapeutic effect through vasopressin-2 receptor in which of the following;
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vasopressin causes vasoconstriction via V1 receptors on blood vessels. It is useful for stopping bleeding from oesophageal varices.

choices.text: Vaptans are approved by FDA for its treatment
Water-loading test can be used for diagnosis of the condition
Urine sodium is usually low or normal in these patients
Serum sodium may be as low as 125 mEq/L in these patients

questions.text: All of the following are true about SIADH except –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Natriuresis occurs in SIADH increasing urinary sodium excretion.

questions.text: The syndrome of SIADH is characterized by the following:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

SIADH is characterized by dilution hyponatremia & natriuresis.

choices.text: Basal ACTH level is likely to be low.
Pitutary MRI will visualize all ACTH secreting tumors
Circulating corticotropin releasing hormone is likely to be elevated
Serum potassium level <3.3 mmol/L is suggestive of ectopic ACTH production

questions.text: Which of the following is true about cushing syndrome :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypokalaemic alkalosis is seen in Ectopic ACTH producing tumors which cause Cushing Syndrome.

choices.text: Low dose dexamethasone suppress cortisone secretion.
CA of adrenal is more common than adenoma.
Increased ACTH secretion is the commonest cause.

questions.text: About cushing syndrome,true is:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pitutary adenoma with increased ACTH secretion is most common endogenous cause of Cushing Syndrome .

questions.text: Lalloo,50 year old ,a chronic smoker,presents wih history of hemoptysis.He was having truncal obesity and hypertension.He had elevated ACTH level which was not suppressible with high dose of dexamethasone.What would be most probable diagnosis:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ectopic ACTH producing lung cancer shows no suppression with high dose dexa test.

choices.text: Low plasma rennin activity that is not stimulated by volume depletion
Hyperaldosteronism i.e. increased aldosterone secretion which is not suppressed by volume expansion

questions.text: Primary hyperaldosteronism can be diagnosed by all of the following criteria except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome) is characterized by hypokalemic alkalosis.

questions.text: Addison’s disease was first reported by Thomas Addison. It is still being widely reported from various parts of the world/throughout the world. Which of the following is the most common cause of Addison’s disease in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most common cause of Addison disease in the world is Autoimmune.
Most common cause of Addison disease in developing countries is TB.

choices.text: Solitary adenoma is most common cause.

questions.text: All are true about hyperparathyroidism except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Post thyroidectomy hypoparathyroidism is seen.

choices.text: Increase in 24 hour urinary calcium excretion.

questions.text: Not a marker for Primary hyperparathyroidism:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

There is no increase OF Calcitonin in  hyperparathyroidism

choices.text: It is due to end organ insensitivity.
Associated with low levels of calcium and phosphate.
Albright dystrophy is associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: True regarding pseudohypoparathyroidism include all except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

There is rebound increase in serum level of PTH due to PTH resistance.

questions.text: A 75 year old lady with fracture neck of femur presents with two days history of altered sensorium and decreased urine outpt.Serum calcium is 15.5 mg/dL, urea -140 mg/dl,createnine is 2 mg/Dl.All of the following are useful for immediate management of hypercalcemia except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bisphosphonates have a delayed onset of action in treatment of hypercalcemia ,so it cannot be used for acute management of hypercalcemia.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of hypercalcemia:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Due to increased contraction of anal sphincter constipation is seen in hypercalcemia.

questions.text: Treatment of hypercalcemia includes all except:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thiazide diuretics are useful in treatment of hypocalcemia.

questions.text: The best test to diagnose thyroid related disorder:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TSH is best screening test for diagnosis of thyroid related disorder.

questions.text: A 17-year old girl who was evaluated for short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was low and TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In primary hypothyroidism there is decreased T4 causing increased TSH levels.

questions.text: A patient meets with an accident with resultant transaction of the pituitary stalk ,what will not occur:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Secretion of insulin from Beta cells of pancreas is not regulated by Pituitary gland.

choices.text: Morning peak of plasma cortisol level.
Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia.

questions.text: A patient has neurosurgery for a pituitary tumor that requires resection of gland.Which of the following functions of adrenal gland will be preserved in this patient immediately postoperatively ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Sodium retention in hypovolemia is regulated by renin production stimulating Aldosterone release .
